item.title: Cheap oil drags down Russia's ruble
item.description: Read full story for latest details.
item.ExtractedText: Cheap oil drags down Russia's ruble by Ivana Kottasova @ivanakottasova August 17, 2015: 7:32 AM ET Vladimir Putin in 90 Seconds The Russian ruble has hit a new six-month low against the dollar, as Moscow struggles with tumbling oil prices and economic sanctions. The currency plunged 1.3% to 65.7 rubles per dollar in the early hours of Monday. It has since recovered to 65.5 per dollar. Russia's central bank stopped buying foreign reserves in July, hoping to prevent the ruble from falling further. But it didn't help -- the ruble has dropped 44.8% against the dollar in the last year and 12% in the last month. The currency has been hit hard by the collapse in oil prices. That's because around half of Russia's government revenue comes from the oil industry. The country's budget is based on the assumption it could sell its oil for $50 per barrel or more. But oil is now trading below $42 a barrel , just a year after reaching $115 last summer.
